quiz.title: Function Notation
quiz.subtitle: Unit 3.3: Using f(x) Notation for Functions
quiz.subject: Mathematics

questions.question: If g(t) = t² - 4, what is g(-2)?
Based on the table, what is f(x)?
questions.explanation: Check: f(1)=2(1)+1=3 ✓, f(2)=2(2)+1=5 ✓, f(3)=2(3)+1=7 ✓. Pattern: each output is 1 more than twice the input.

questions.question: What function rule matches this table?
questions.explanation: f(x) is always 4, regardless of x. This is a constant function: f(-2)=4, f(0)=4, f(3)=4, f(5)=4.

questions.question: Given f(x) = x/2 + 1, what is f(6)?
What does the 'x' represent in f(x)?
questions.explanation: In f(x), x is the input variable. It's the value we substitute into the function.

questions.question: If f(x) = 3 and x = 7, what is f(7)?
questions.explanation: f(x) = 3 means the function always outputs 3, regardless of input. So f(7) = 3.

questions.question: Which shows correct function notation?
questions.explanation: All are valid notations: f(x)=, arrow notation f:x→, and even f × x though less common.
